(1) The Washington Meeting
It was a significant meeting! We of NAEB can take pride in
having initiated it*
Being mailed under separate cover (to those of you who were
not there) is some material which describes what went on, such
as the program, a list of participants, and copies of several
of the principal speeches.
The quality of the talks was up to the very best I have heard
anywhere at a conference, convention or institute. We got off to
an excellent start Monday morning with fine statements by Novice
G* Fawcett, President of Ohio State University, and William Go
Carr, executive secretary of the NEA* Marshall McLuhan of
Toronto University threw us a couple of fast curves with his
distinctions between ideas expressed in print and through the
electronic media. Whether or not one agreed with his point,
though, the overall effect was highly stimulating* Monday
afternoon*s reports provided important information on the status
of television, films, research, and radio.
Tuesday morning maintained the high standards of the previous
day* Those of you who have heard Leonard Marks in action need
only be told that he was up to his usual level of performance*
David Stewart gave a good summary of the status of reservations,
after which Edgar Dale provided a superb review of the general
problem of introducing mass media from the year 4000 B.C* to
date, while Wanda Mitchell gave us the teacher’s point of view*
The Tuesday afternoon sessions followed through logically from
this one*
